reviewText:
Early Access Review

Rogue system is a space ship SIMULATOR.  No I didn't just accidently hit caps lock. It's in caps as this is the what the game is. It's more like DCS and Kerbal space program than it is space games like Elite, X series, Star Citizen and No Man's Sky.  There isn't a game like this and it fills a niche in the market for a realistic, highly detailed, complex and rewarding space ship study simulator.


The game is currently in Alpha so it's still in development. There's only a couple of tutorials, a mission and a sandbox to faff in. There's only one ship currently. Even so this is something special and if the game sounds interesting to you I highly recommend giving it a try.
voteText: 39 of 40 people (98%) found this review helpful 2 people found this review funny

reviewText:
Early Access Review

I bought Rogue System from ISI a year ago and have been dipping into RS on and off since then. It's great to see it get more exposure on Steam. As a Space Sim fan since Wing Commander and I-war I can safely say this is the most immersive space ship flying simulator there is. The atmosphere the game evokes is perfect. When you hear the satisfying click of a button, you can hear the coolant flowing through the pipes, reactants being expelled and the ship comes alive.

There is nothing like this on the market at the moment. A first person KSP with pre-produced ships and a hard sci-fi approach to flying them scratches a nerd itch I didn't know I had.

Having said that the game is only produced by one developer and is a bit bare bones in terms of volume of content. The interactive systems are what you are going to buy this for now though. I cannot wait to see how the game grows from here.

Tldr: A certified reccommendation for Space Sim fans with a hardcore realistic streak.
voteText: 19 of 20 people (95%) found this review helpful 2 people found this review funny

reviewText:
Early Access Review

This game is fantastic, the best way to describe what it's trying to accomplish, is kinda like DCS + Orbiter. The simulation is really accurate and painstainkly realistic, the physics are fantastic, and it tries REALLY hard to stick to current tech + what we realisticly think future tech will look like Ressonant Cavity Thrusters (check out this link if you want to learn more: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/RF_resonant_cavity_thruster).

However, bear in mind that this game is in early access for a reason! it's currently rather feature slim and as of now there's not much to do other then mess around with your ship and do orbital flight + transfers.

Despite this, I would like to say that this game is already REALLY fun and enjoyable, the developer (who might  I mention is extreamly active on both readdit and the offical forums) also has a fantastic and very detailed road map layed about about what he wants to do based on how well the game does on steam,

I've had this game since a month after it was first purchasable on their site, and I must say the purchase was 100% worth it! You can see the love and care the dev puts into this title and the progress is extreamly visible and tangilble.

--------------

All in all I recommend this game to anyone that wants a in-depth sim expirances of what future space flight could verry well turn out to be like and wants to watch this game grow into something amazing!

Early Access Review

It's basicly set up like a high quality flight simulator, but in space. Every button is clickable and serves a purpose, and if done in the wrong order will cause system failures. The orbital dynamics are spot on. The one ship (so far) is set up very well to learn on, and the tutorials are of good quality. There isn't much to do, but the syastem available is well done and is fun to just buzz around.  Definately looking forward to what gets added.

I would definately recomend this for anyone who love flight sims and space sims.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Note: I bought this from the website when it was released in the eAccess program (about 6 months ago?) I spent about 40 hours in it.

If you want realism, clickable cockpit controls, logical manuver methodologies, orbital mechaincs, in your space game - look no further. Docking manually in this sim feels like the great accomplishment it is. The cockpits remind me of a DCS study sim for a modern combat jet. This has the right to be called a simulation - There are many proceedures and contingences to memorize and perfect, and there is are few 'magic' sci-fi systems - it all seems plausable.

There is not a lot to do yet except run though the tutorials and practice docking, navagation and manuver in a limited system, but seeing the developers progress over the last period prior to Steam EA release, I believe he will deliver a great space sim.

Rogue System is DSC mixed with KSP.  The amount of detail in the ships system is immense, with more planned.  While there isn't alot of content yet, the ground work is laid for an epic experience.

Cons:

Conclusion:
This is the first review I've ever posted online.  Why do one now? Because I feel the potential of this game is amazing.  Everyone needs to buy it, so that the developer can hire a team and speed up the process.  I need more :)

reviewText:
Early Access Review

I'd like to make it clear that I have previous game time that steam will not represent

What is Rogue System?
Rogue System is a hardcore space simulation, the best way to put it is DCS in space or ArmA for spacecraft. This style of game comes with a steep learning curve, but rewards players that take the time to understand the game. Rogue System has you pilot a ship with near unlimited access to the systems it has, you will balance cooling systems and manage power and feel like some kind of spacecraft god whilst doing so. For now, however, I'll talk about what the game is currently.

Is it good?
Well.. coming from a KSP and ArmA fan.. yes, the orbital mechanics are accurate and managing the ship is satisfying when you have the hang of it. All controls in the game are rebindable and I have no problem hooking up various controls to my X55 Hotas. But it is hard to think of more that the game has right now that is good. As it stands there are few missions to participate in with a sandbox *fly around and do whatever* being most of the story for now.

So it's bad?
Not strictly speaking.. it's in a very early state which is another way of saying barely any missions, one work-in-progress ship and infrequent updates. Rogue System has solid foundations for a hardcore space sim but it'll be a long time in development before we see any kind of final release. Bugs are present and most of the game is still concept art. Which make it hard to get you to pay the £23 price tag.

Should I buy it?
At this stage most likely no for most people. Rogue System will become a great sim if it does what it says it will at the end of the road, but if you want to buy this game to enjoy a space sim. Wait untill it's finished, however, If you want to support the developer in their endevaours then feel free to purchase. I will personally be upvoting this game, as I feel that it has great potential given time.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Despite my low Steam playtime, I have experience from this game for 10+ hours in the pre-Steam release.

If you're a fan of hyper-detailed simulation games and want to feel like you're carefully configuring and flying a spaceship rather than just hitting 'start' and engaging in flashy dogfights, this is for you. As the developer notes, it's slim on playable content content as of the current early access release (May 2016), but this is largely due to the from the ground up" style the developer is currently employing; most of the patch notes in the pre-Steam phase have involved underlying ship systems and mechanics fixes that will make for an unusually detailed simulation base to build upon.

After following the development for over a year
date: I can assure any potential buyers that the developer is firmly committed for the long haul to producing a quality product. If you decide to purchase
recommended: you can hop right in and get a feel for the various ship subsystems and experience truly being in the cockpit of a space vessel
hoursPlayed: then join us in awaiting the content to come."

reviewText:
Early Access Review

I watched this game for a long time before I committed to backing it. I love the idea of the game; but what persuaded me to commit was my perception of the developer, Michael. His intent is to make a spaceship game with integrity, based on real world physics, and technology that can be scientifically plausible.

He goes the whole way--what can only be described as the hardcore way--ship systems with actual functionality, interactions and dependencies, in space that is correctly simulated with actual full Newtonian flight and orbital mechanics. You need to learn how to operate your ship and actually pilot it. This is not an arcade game, and I love it for that reason.

This is a game" that I can take seriously
date: and that is a great achievement. For me
recommended: it goes beyond fun. It gives me a satisfaction and enjoyment that only a hardcore spaceship game can bring; and I love it more for that reason.\n\nThis is early access and it is feature light at the moment I am writing this. Seeing how this game has developed
voteText: I am totally looking forward to the finished Core Module and then the later Expansion Modules.\n\nI can only recommend this game to you. If you want to play a game that is unique

reviewText:
Early Access Review

[edit: I'll keep this review updated with the development of the game]

I have been playing and supporting this game for about a year now migrated the licence to steam.

It is a very complex futuristic spaceship simulator. of course in early acces so quite limited on documentation and not ready for arcade shooter players.

What I really like is the complexity. and if you are a bit of a nerd your self you might just find this your cup of tea.

Weather it is 'realistic' as many claim,. I'm not sure. I personally imagine that in the future, the start up procedure would be much easier, mutch more automated, more like the 777 and less like a DC10 if you know what I mean.
[edit] Ship AI is announced but not yet implemented. It will make ship management more automated. I imagine it will still be possible to override AI in abnormal situations.

Nevertheless a very cool technical space craft simulator/game. Big thumbs up!

reviewText:
Early Access Review

I will just say this, if you like DCS, if you like Kerbal Space Program's adherence to realistic space physics and orbital mechanics, if you like Orbiter, then, this game is a good home for your virtual near future space flight fantasies.

Like most today, I am a cynic when it comes to all these seemingly unfinished E.Access games. However, last year I had the opportunity completely by dumb chance to tryout RogSys and it was and has been tremendous fun despite its early state.  So far the dev has been a very professional and open communicator with his customers/players/community. I believe he's been at this game for over 3 years and has not shown any sign of giving up, so I'm confident at the very least we'll see a playable proper campaign, if not more.

It's in very early stages so READ the duscussions and reviews, visit the forums and WATCH some videos of what it's like first.  A lot of the foundation work is in, but there isn't too much as of this writing in the typical gameplay" sense as the dev is still obviously in very early access stages. Most of what you CAN do is:

- operate the Flying Fox support spaceship from full cold startup and shutdown
recommended: managing systems etc.\n- practice the tutorials
voteText: \n- explore the solar system
votesHelpful: repairs) and missions to be added in upcoming updates.\n\nAdditional expansion modules will be feasible with multiplayer
votesTotal: multi-crew ships and freelancer style play
votesFunny: if we get more players to buy in and support the dev hire additional help.\n\nThe $30 price may be steep for its current state
column16: it is going to keep on updating and more goodies will be here eventually. Keep this one on your wishlist at the very least!"

reviewText:
Early Access Review

The most promising space/space ship simulator to date.

In this simulator, every single button in your cockpit is usable and serves important functions, and there's a whole lot of buttons with even more coming!
I spent endless hours just redoing the tutorial to power up my ship over and over, until I could memorize the order and learn which buttons do what. Push the wrong button, or push it at the wrong time and your ship may well shutdown or worse, leaving you with nothing but a floating coffin in space.
Having no previous experience with simulators that are this complex, I was absolutely thrilled to find this new challenge.
The feeling when you first manage to power up your highly advanced ship on your own, undock it and fly it to a new moon or planet, then rendevouz with a new station and dock to it is quite satisfying.

I have never spent this many hours in a early access that has this little content until now.
I find my self checking for updates and new content to this game every day, as it's just that good.

If you love space, space games/simulators, and you are up to a real challenge, this game is definitely for you!

Ok folks,

I wanted to complete the 6 possible achievements before writing this review. Took about 6 hours. I enjoy these kinds of simulations, and honestly found this game to be quite amazing. I also play “Space Shuttle Mission Simulator” which has a similar complexity feel to it. Love the control panel look, find the space view graphics to be extremely good. Even in its early access state, the game is well worth the cost and I can't wait to see more content. This game seems to be EXTREAMLY stable, so my hats off to the developers for creating a complex game with amazing stability. Other Simulation game companies can learn a lesson from this one, for other game companies haven't obtained this kind of stability.

Small changes that would be cool are actual voice acting within the comms system. Buttons that FLASH" to grab your attention. Looks like auto docking is already being considered. Maybe a “point and click” navigation map system. Problem is

reviewText:
Early Access Review

I bought this game in early access phase before Steam so have some experience with it before the Steam Release. Personally I love it development is slow but heading in the direction I want it to head in consistently. The dev doesn't change direction every five minutes but is quick to respond to issues while continually fleshing out the game and sim aspects of Rogue System.
If you like Orbiter Sim this is for you. If you like Kerbal Space Program but want something a bit more simulation focused then this is for you. If you like Elite Dangerous but want something more consistent and realistic (The NPC's will fly according to the same rules and using the same systems as the player) This is definitely for you. If you just want pew pew then maybe wait until it is a bit further down the line or get it now to make sure it gets there.
I am hoping this game gets the exposure it deserves. I love it. It really is the only game of it's kind at the moment. If Aurora 4x is space simulation's Dwarf Fortress then Rogue System is Space Simulation's Elite Dangerous.
I highly recommend it.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

This has great potential and is something I have always wanted more than almost any game.

However despite all this I cannot recommend this after further investigation this game has been in development/alpha for almost 3 years and appears to have regressed in progression.

You wont be able to fly the ship that you see scott manly flying or using nearly any of the features besides basic functions (sensors arent implemented fully yet even). Instead you get a half complete gunless/bad looking ship. Apparently these have been put back to the drawing table due to a change. (this was a terribly terrible idea to release it on steam in such a state).

I bought it instantly after seeing it was on steam since I remember seeing footage of people playing it.

Don't do that.

Instead wait until more of the game is released for everyones sake instead of encouraging this forever alpha trend in gaming.
